citations.narrative:
A second request to inspect the records on the zebu and mini cows at the facility, including the nine zebu that were
bought at an auction in MO on April 6, 2023, and a Dingo that was received/transported from a zoo in MI on December 6,
2023 was refused. There are two health certificates from the Minnesota Board of Animal Health that show the licensee did
receive 2 miniature Scottish highlanders on February 2, 2024, and 2 Highlander on March 5, 2024, from a facility in MN.
When asked to look at the records for any exotic cattle he bought, transported, or sold since December 2023, the licensee
would not produce any records and advised he did not have to produce any records if he tells the USDA that he is only
using the animals for agricultural activities. Upon being asked multiple times by the licensee about whether agricultural
animals are regulated, it was explained to the licensee multiple times that the records of animals need to be disclosed
during an inspection to determine if regulated activities are or are not being conducted.
The refusal of a licensee to allow inspectors to look at records(acquisition/dispositions) of a facility does not provide for
proper traceability of regulated animals and makes it impossible to determine the origin/disposition and use of animals
being bought/sold/used at a facility. Only after seeing the records on the animals in question (exotics or domestic) can it
be determined by inspectors if the animals are being used for regulated vs unregulated business.
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make,
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her
control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing nesting or
rearing activities.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
LYNNE WHITE-SHIM, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Critical Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A second request to inspect the records on the zebu and mini cows at the facility, including the nine zebu that were 
bought at an auction in MO on April 6, 2023, and a Dingo that was received/transported from a zoo in MI on December 6, 
2023 was refused. There are two health certificates from the Minnesota Board of Animal Health that show the licensee did 
receive 2 miniature Scottish highlanders on February 2, 2024, and 2 Highlander on March 5, 2024, from a facility in MN. 
When asked to look at the records for any exotic cattle he bought, transported, or sold since December 2023, the licensee 
would not produce any records and advised he did not have to produce any records if he tells the USDA that he is only 
using the animals for agricultural activities. Upon being asked multiple times by the licensee about whether agricultural 
animals are regulated, it was explained to the licensee multiple times that the records of animals need to be disclosed 
during an inspection to determine if regulated activities are or are not being conducted.  
 
The refusal of a licensee to allow inspectors to look at records(acquisition/dispositions) of a facility does not provide for 
proper traceability of regulated animals and makes it impossible to determine the origin/disposition and use of animals 
being bought/sold/used at a facility. Only after seeing the records on the animals in question (exotics or domestic) can it 
be determined by inspectors if the animals are being used for regulated vs unregulated business.  
 
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make, 
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other 
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her 
control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing nesting or 
rearing activities. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
LYNNE WHITE-SHIM, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
